0.28.text:
Cathy Wurzer: It’s been a long campaign,
it’s almost over, but not before we hear

3.97.text:
from the candidates in one final debate of
the 2014 election season in Minnesota. This

9.03.text:
one pits incumbent U.S. Democratic Senator
Al Franken, who’s finishing up his first

12.84.text:
term, against the Republican challenger, political
newcomer and businessman Mike McFadden. I’m

17.24.text:
Cathy Wurzer, the host of Morning Edition
on Minnesota Public Radio News, along with

20.85.text: Kerri Miller from the Daily Circuit.

22.45.text:
Kerri Miller: Hello there, welcome everyone.
I’ve always liked the way that Supreme Court

27.20.text:
Justice Louis Brandeis thought about polit
political voting and the roles that voters

33.83.text:
play in politics. He said, “The most important
political office is that of the private citizen.”

40.47.text:
In other words, your vote counts. Our goal
tonight, is to speed you on your way to that

45.92.text:
vote, with important information and more
information about these candidates for the

50.89.text:
U.S. Senate. So shall we begin? Welcome everyone,
good to have you here.

58.12.text:
CW: Glad you’re with us. Thanks to the candidates,
glad you’re here.

62.75.text:
KM: Ah Senator Franken, your term in the Senate
has been characterized by many as a time in

69.02.text:
which you’ve eschewed your previous career
as a comedian and you’ve played it safe.

75.08.text:
You’ve even been proudly boring at times.
One voter, Paula Manor of Northfield, told

81.44.text:
the Washington Post recently about you, “I’d
like to see him take more risk.” So the

87.17.text:
question is, if you’re constantly playing
it safe, are you really making a difference?

Al Franken: Well ah I don’t constantly play
it safe. I don’t think I’ve played it

98.65.text:
safe. I’ve – taken on ah a lot of special
interests. Ah one of the first bills I did

was ah women in Iraq and Afghanistan had been
sexually assaulted ah by ah military contractors.

And they had signed employment contracts in
which there was mandatory arbitration. So

125.85.text:
these women couldn’t go to court. So I stood
up and said “This is wrong. These women

131.69.text:
should be able to have their day in court.”
And I had actually the Defense Department

136.87.text:
against me. (laughs) I had defense contractors
against me. I had ah 30 Republicans, ah my

144.86.text:
colleague Jeff Sessions, leading the fight
against me. On this. But I won.

fight against, is mandatory arbitration. Ah
and so I won that battle, and that was after

I may finish on this. The reason the reason

2686.84.text:
the federal government’s involved here is
right now, the way charter schools are funded,

2690.91.text:
they don’t get any local dollars. They get
state dollars Kerri and they get federal dollars.

2695.58.text:
And as a U.S. senator, I don’t want federal
dollars going into a broken school district.

2699.83.text:
I’d rather see those allocated to dramatically
increase the number of charter schools in

2704.86.text:
those areas. So that all children in Minnesota,
have the access to a first-class education,

2709.96.text:
regardless of zip code. And nothing – Al
has been on the Education Committee for the

2714.32.text:
last six years – he’s complicit in these
results. Things aren’t getting better in

2718.16.text: the inner city. They’re getting worse.

2719.16.text:
KM: Response, and then we’ll go into the
Affordable Care Act.

2722.03.text:
AF: Well, I’d like to talk a little about
the achievement gap. And I think it is a travesty.

2727.73.text:
That we have such a big achievement gap in
Minnesota. We are making some improvement

2732.43.text:
in the state level. Our black fourth graders
are fourth in the nation. We have, we were

2740.39.text:
among fourth graders for black and Latinos,
we we’re the only state in the country that

2746.76.text:
closed the achievement gap ah among them.
Now here – I would like, just like to talk

2752.44.text:
about closing the achievement gap and what
I think we should do. Ah early childhood education

2760.67.text:
to me is one of the most important things
that we can do. I talked to Angela ah Harvala.

2766.50.text:
You might have heard her name. She won the
National Milken Award. Ah, was one of the

2771.70.text:
best teachers in the country. She teaches
fifth grade in at Princeton,

2776.27.text:
AF: Minnesota. I called her up just to congratulate
her, and we started talking about this. And

2779.60.text:
she talked about early childhood education.
Art Rollnick, who’s at the University of

2784.34.text:
Minnesota who studies the economics of early
childhood education. Tim Penny, whose southern

2790.23.text:
Minnesota Initiative Foundation invests 40%
of what they do is on early childhood education.

2795.49.text:
Here is what Art Rollnick has found in terms
of return on investment. “A child who has

2803.10.text:
a quality early childhood education is less
likely to be special ed, less likely to be

2809.43.text: left back a grade, has better health outcomes,

2812.65.text:
AF: the girls are less likely to get pregnant,
they’re more likely to graduate college

2817.19.text:
– ah high school, more likely to go to college,
more likely to have a good job, and pay taxes

2824.52.text: AF: and much less likely to go to prison.

2825.85.text: CW: So Mr. McFadden, do you

2828.87.text:
AF: So this is
MM: I don’t disagree with that. I think

2831.11.text:
CW: is more investment needed in early childhood
education?

2832.24.text:
MM: Look, there’s nothing more important
than our children. There’s nothing more

2835.00.text:
important than our children and our investment,
all our children, regardless of zip code.

2839.03.text:
Early childhood education is a very important
part of the equation. But what everyone in

2843.38.text:
this state needs to know, and I’m telling
ya Kerri and Cathy, cause I’ve gone around

2846.32.text:
this whole state, so few people know that
we have the worst outcomes in the country

2851.25.text:
for students of color. And we’re spending
$21,000 per child in the Minneapolis school

2857.84.text:
CW: And the answer in your view is more money
into charter schools.

2860.87.text:
MM: Yeah, I I wanna revolutionize how we do
education

2863.88.text:
CW: Senator, is that is that the way to resolve
that?

2867.14.text:
AF: I have nothing against charter schools.
My daughter runs ah the after-school programs

2875.50.text:
at three charter schools in Washington D.C.
They are very successful.

2879.07.text: KM: How about the idea that Mr. McFadden has

2881.07.text:
MM: But but nothing has been done, nothing
has been done for six years while you’ve

2885.92.text:
AF: Actually, actually we’ve done some very
good things in terms of -- there’s other

2891.23.text:
areas that we need to talk about, but the
fact

2892.86.text:
MM: The outcomes are atrocious! They’re
immoral, what’s happening!

2895.01.text: KM: Is it, is it possible that you could

2898.39.text:
KM: could you address the suggestion that
he made, though, about investing more money

2906.79.text:
AF: Okay. Thank you. (audience laughs) Ah
charter schools also have spotty records.

2913.40.text:
We have some very successful charter schools
and we have some that aren’t very good.

2918.49.text:
And when that happens, and a kid goes to a
charter school that fails them, that public

2923.06.text: school money goes to – I I want

2926.57.text: AF: to make sure that our

2928.57.text:
AF: I want to make sure (laughs) I’m sorry,
I want to make sure that our public schools

2933.62.text:
ah get what they need. And what I want to
work on, are here’s the areas where I would

2940.38.text: work: on assessments, we made a lot of progress

2945.16.text:
AF: over the last several years on making
sure that we’re measuring each kid’s growth

2950.26.text: instead of holding every kid responsible

2954.98.text:
MM: You’ve been in office for six years,
we have the worst outcomes

2959.24.text:
MM: And we, we pioneer charter schools in
Minnesota. And yes, there’s some charter

2963.52.text:
schools that are not good. But we’ve been
doin it for 20 years now and we have multiple

2968.35.text:
multiple multiple examples of ones that are
doin great things. And we should replicate

2973.10.text:
‘em as fast as we can. As you keep talkin
about all these different things that the

2977.44.text:
federal government can do. In terms of -- our
kids aren’t getting a great education.

2982.65.text:
KM: Do do either of you think Race to the
Top has helped?

2989.42.text:
AF: I think it has put money into things that
like early childhood education, for example,

2997.36.text:
we won a Race to the Top grant ah that is
ah helping our early childhood education in

3008.64.text:
KM: four billion dollars in taxpayer money
so far

3010.83.text:
KM: Has it -- do you see any evidence that
it has

3012.06.text:
MM: No, I don’t think we’re gettin a return
that we deserve for that. It’s a lot of

3014.69.text:
money. And here Kerri here’s y’know – we
spend a lot on education in this country.

3020.40.text:
We spend a lot in this state. And we should.
They’re our children. But the outcomes we’re

3024.65.text:
getting are unacceptable. And I’m so tired
– for 30 years I’ve been hearing about

3028.31.text:
how things are gonna get better, we need more
money more money. It’s not a money issue.

3033.22.text:
CW: Say, speaking of money, I’ve got a quick
audience question. “Many of us are struggling

3037.14.text:
with unfair student loan repayment plans.
What can be done, and what will you do?”

3044.14.text:
MM: Ah, well I’d like to see students be
able to refinance their loans. I’d also

3050.71.text:
like to see more transparency at the college
levels, as a father of six kids, three of

3056.15.text:
‘em are in college, ah y’know education
at colleges, college educations, have gone

3060.53.text:
up something like 2-1/2 times the rate of
inflation for over 20 years. And it’s the

3064.76.text:
most opaque industry. Y’know, you don’t
find out what your financial aid package is

3068.98.text:
until the very end, and there’s no transparency.
I would like colleges to have to let students

3075.00.text:
know what their job placement is, by major,
and what their what what percent of their

3079.72.text:
kids are getting hired and what their average
salaries are. So that students can make an

3084.40.text:
KM: So you’re talking about legislation
to require colleges to disclose that.

3090.50.text: KM: At at what point? The college visit? When?

3092.23.text:
MM: Ah ah I’d like it I’d like to be on
the publicly available information so that

3098.45.text: you can go and find pricing. Just like

3099.53.text:
KM: Is this something that you two agree on
again?

3101.60.text:
AF: This is actually something that is a piece
of legislation that I’ve offered that Chuck

3110.02.text:
AF: and Marco Rubio Marco Rubio, is on another
one on transparency, it’s called the Net

3116.09.text:
Cost Calculator. And what it does is, you
can a lot of students don’t go to a college

3123.85.text:
because they think they’re gonna be priced
out of it. But you can require, what I wanna

3128.79.text:
do is require colleges on their Web page to
put a Net Cost Calculator so you can figure

3134.36.text: out how much it’s gonna cost you. Now Marc

3136.06.text: KM: So you two agree on this?

3137.50.text:
AF: Well, not only do we agree on it, I’ve
acted on it and had legislation that’s bipartisan.

3144.81.text: MM: But it hasn’t turned into law yet

3146.95.text: AF: Not yet, but we are

3149.08.text: MM: I mean, there’s a lot of

3150.08.text:
AF: We are marking up, we are going to be
marking up a higher education bill ah, it’s

3155.06.text:
CW: Do you agree about refinancing with Mr.
McFadden? Do you agree that students should

3158.48.text: be able to refinance their student loans?

3159.76.text:
AF: I introduced the bill in the Senate to
refi – so to allow 560,000 Minnesotans to

3170.79.text:
refinance their student loans. Mr. McFadden
has criticized me for this, and he’s criticized

3177.62.text:
me because – Elizabeth Warren and I did
this – and we pay for it because the actual

3186.37.text:
federal government makes profits off these
student loans, so we have to pay for it, and

3191.03.text: the way we pay for it is the Buffett Rule.

3194.89.text:
KM: We’re a little short on time, I’d
like to get one more topic in. Could you

3197.98.text:
AF: Well he (to MM) would protect people who
make over a million dollars a year, which

3202.82.text:
is the top one quarter of one percent in Minnesota,
so that

3206.76.text:
MM: Al, I I I would like, I would like to
see

3209.72.text:
AF: 560,000 Minnesotans can’t refinance
their student loans.

3211.43.text:
MM: If if if the federal government’s making
money off of it, then there’s no issue.

3216.35.text:
Then there’s money there to pay for this.
The federal government’s a 3-1/2 trillion

3221.36.text:
dollar budget, and the way – you you have
not been a good fiduciary of that or steward

3228.68.text: MM: over the last six years.

3229.68.text:
KM: Could, we’re we’re a little short
on time.

3230.68.text: AF: You need to offset it.

3232.68.text:
MM: No you just said they’re makin a profit
on it.

3234.68.text:
KM: We don’t have as much time as I had
hoped, gentlemen, to talk about the Affordable

3238.75.text:
Care Act, but I do have a question that I
think will produce a shorter answer. I hope.

3245.88.text:
KM: Honeywell has a new health benefits rule
under the Affordable Care Act. Where they’re

3253.42.text:
going to penalize employees who won’t agree
to blood and medical tests to identify whether

3259.41.text:
they smoke or have diabetes or high blood
pressure or other problems. Honeywell can

3265.61.text:
do this under the ACA, and they say they need
to do it to bring their healthcare costs under

3272.03.text: control. Are they doing the right thing? Senator?

3275.17.text:
AF: Well, the one area that we’re we are
trying to bring healthcare costs down are

3282.72.text:
in areas of preventable diseases. And ah we’re
not penalizing someone for having a pre-existing

3290.13.text:
condition. But the one area where you do have
to pay more for your policy is if you smoke.

3296.41.text:
KM: So is Honeywell doing the right thing,
in instituting these new rules?

3300.52.text:
AF: I’m not sure that (laughs) a blood test
is is the right way to go. I would ah try

3305.89.text: to go on the honor system. I think that

3308.76.text:
CW: There’s a minute left before I need
to get out of this part.

3311.28.text:
MM: The the the Affordable Care Act is the
the cost – we have a healthcare issue in

3316.18.text:
this country. Al knows it, Kerri you know
it, Cathy you know it. I just fundamentally

3320.84.text: believe that the ACA is not the right solution.

3323.17.text: KM: Is a company like Honeywell

3326.61.text:
KM do you believe in trying to control healthcare
costs

3330.07.text:
MM: They have to – I believe that that’s
their right to do.

3334.33.text:
MM: If they want to do it – we have we have
a huge cost issue with healthcare in this

3338.36.text:
country. That we have to address, and people
have to have skin in the game. And they have

3342.33.text:
to understand that if they have certain behaviors,
that it’s gonna cost more. It’s their

3345.85.text: right to participate in those behaviors.

3347.93.text:
KM: (to AF) You say they should not be using
the rules this way. Briefly.

3351.90.text:
AF: I y’know, I feel a little queasy about
it. About forcing employees to take blood

3356.74.text:
tests. But no – this this is the one area
where we’re saying if you smoke, you pay

3361.85.text:
MM: When you get, when you get life insurance,
and you go, you you you have to take blood

3365.10.text:
tests. I mean you can decide not to – and
then you pay the penalty on it. I, we have

3370.02.text:
a cost issue. Y’know, PreferredOne’s up
63% and healthcare costs

3374.34.text:
CW: I want to ask you, we need to get into
closing statements here

3377.15.text:
CW: because we’re running out of time. I’m
sorry gentlemen.

3379.72.text:
CW: Senator Franken, I want you to begin your
closing statement at this point, and then

3383.97.text:
AF: Well, I want to, I wanna thank the people
of Minnesota for the honor of representing

3389.40.text:
you in the United States Senate. I know that
ah some Minnesotans didn’t know quite what

3396.55.text:
to expect from me – ah but I think most
have seen that I work hard. And I work hard

3403.39.text:
for the benefit of all Minnesotans. Ah to
reform the workforce training system in our

3413.20.text:
country. To write the Energy Title on the
bipartisan Farm Bill to make sure that our

3419.67.text:
schoolchildren can get mental health treatment
in our schools. Ah I’ve gone – I’ve

3428.96.text:
fought for common ground, but I also will
fight to stand my ground when powerful interests

3435.74.text:
come after the middle class. I believe that
the economy works

3441.53.text:
AF: from the middle out, not the top down,
I ah I hope that your audience will vote for

3447.18.text:
me, so it will give me the honor of returning
to the United States Senate

3451.84.text:
AF: to work for Americans, for Minnesotans
who simply want the opportunity to build a

3458.24.text:
MM: Cathy, Kerri, Al, thank you. I really
appreciate the audience. I thank you, you’ve

3462.12.text:
been very professional. I I think the decision
is simple here. If you believe the President

3468.27.text:
has done a good job, then vote for Al Franken.
If you believe the hyperpartisan Congress

3473.46.text:
in Washington is doin a good job, then vote
for Al Franken. I fundamentally believe that

3479.10.text:
we could be doing so much better. In this
country and in this state. Ah I believe that

3486.20.text:
with the right leadership we could have energy
independence. We can have a first-class education

3491.23.text:
for all students, regardless of zip code.
That we can have effective and efficient government.

3496.77.text:
I want to streamline regulation to unleash
our economic potential. I’ll get the mines

3502.75.text:
open, I’ll get the pipelines built, and
I’ll also get the EPA out of the farmers’

3508.83.text:
fields. I believe our best days are ahead
of us. If we have

3512.66.text:
MM: the right leadership in Washington. I’m
Mike McFadden and I’m running for the U.S.

3517.03.text:
KM: All right! Senator Al Franken, Mike McFadden,
thank you

3518.03.text:
Audience applauds, cheers as candidates and
moderators shake hands.
